elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sect0005">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0070" view="all">Three new mixed-ligand metal-organic frameworks based on 5,5′-(butane-1,4- diyl)-bis(oxy)-diisophthalic acid and transitional metal cations with the help of two ancillary bridging N-donor pyridyl and imidazole linkers, [Zn(L)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>(4,4′-bpy)]·2(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) <ce:bold>(1),</ce:bold> [M(L)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>(bib)]·4(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) (M = Zn <ce:bold>(2),</ce:bold> Co <ce:bold>(3)</ce:bold>), (4,4′-bpy=4,4′–bipyridine, bib=1,4-bis (1H-imidazol-1-yl)-butane), have been synthesized under solvothermal conditions. Their structures and properties were determined by single-crystal and powder X-ray diffraction analyses, IR spectra, elemental analyses and thermogravimetric analyses (TGA). Compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> display a 3D 3-fold interpenetrated frameworks linked by the L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligands, ancillary N-donor linkers and the free water molecules in the crystal lattice. Topological analysis reveals that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are a (4,4)-connected <ce:bold>bbf</ce:bold> topology net with the (6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>·8<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)(6<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>) topology. The effects of the L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> anions, the N-donor ligands, and the metal ions on the structures of the coordination polymers have been discussed. Furthermore, luminescence properties and thermogravimetric properties of these compounds were investigated.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract
Three new mixed-ligand metal-organic frameworks based on 5,5′-(butane-1,4- diyl)-bis(oxy)-diisophthalic acid and transitional metal cations with the help of two ancillary bridging N-donor pyridyl and imidazole linkers, [Zn(L)0.5(4,4′-bpy)]·2(H2O) (1), [M(L)0.5(bib)]·4(H2O) (M = Zn (2), Co (3)), (4,4′-bpy=4,4′–bipyridine, bib=1,4-bis (1H-imidazol-1-yl)-butane), have been synthesized under solvothermal conditions. Their structures and properties were determined by single-crystal and powder X-ray diffraction analyses, IR spectra, elemental analyses and thermogravimetric analyses (TGA). Compounds 1–3 display a 3D 3-fold interpenetrated frameworks linked by the L4− ligands, ancillary N-donor linkers and the free water molecules in the crystal lattice. Topological analysis reveals that 1–3 are a (4,4)-connected bbf topology net with the (64·82)(66) topology. The effects of the L4− anions, the N-donor ligands, and the metal ions on the structures of the coordination polymers have been discussed. Furthermore, luminescence properties and thermogravimetric properties of these compounds were investigated.

other properties: (4,4)-connected bbf topology net with the (6^4·8^2)(6^6) topology

Three new compounds of MOFs have been prepared and characterized. The luminescence properties and thermogravimetric properties of compounds were investigated.



fx1




Introduction
In recent years, the metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) has attracted considerable attention not only for their intriguing architectures  and bewitching topological nets , but also for their potential applications in gas storage substances , luminescent materials , magnetism substances , catalysis , nonlinear optics  and so on. The current research in the fields of MOFs has promoted the design of a target structure with specific properties and functions . Therefore, the investigation of the relationship between the topological structure and the conformation of ligands is a challenging task for chemists working on creating fascinating inorganic function compounds, and it is necessary to research some properties of the resulting coordination polymers.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Recently, flexible multi-carboxylate ligands with two or more aromatic rings were used to build interesting coordination frameworks , especially some flexible frameworks with functional organic groups . The flexibility of the organic flexible multicarboxylate ligands provide the constructed functional MOFs tunable structures, which further have affected the properties . Moreover, when the ancillary ligands are introduced to build the frameworks, the final structures have greater tunability . The ancillary bridging imidazole or pyridine linkers holding different lengths and flexibilities have great effects on the final architectures and topology as well as coordination modes and molecular conformations of multicarboxylate acids . Therefore, preparing novel functional MOFs using such kinds of flexible multicarboxylate and ancillary bridging imidazole or pyridine linkers should be attempted. In this article, we have chosen the flexible multicarboxylic acid, namely, 5,5′-(butane-1,4-diyl)-bis(oxy)-diisophthalic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L), and two ancillary bridging imidazole or pyridine linkers, namely, 4,4-bipyridine (4,4′-bpy)  and 1,4-bis (1H-imidazol-1-yl)-butane (bib) . Herein, three 3D 3-fold interpenetrated frameworks were obtained through a mix ligand strategy under similar solvothermal reactions, [Zn(L)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>(4,4′-bpy)]·2(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) <ce:bold>(1),</ce:bold> [M (L)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>(bib)]·4(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) (M = Zn <ce:bold>(2),</ce:bold> Co <ce:bold>(3)</ce:bold>) (). Moreover, the syntheses, crystal structures, topologies, thermal stabilities and photoluminescent properties are reported in this paper.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Recently, flexible multi-carboxylate ligands with two or more aromatic rings were used to build interesting coordination frameworks , especially some flexible frameworks with functional organic groups . The flexibility of the organic flexible multicarboxylate ligands provide the constructed functional MOFs tunable structures, which further have affected the properties . Moreover, when the ancillary ligands are introduced to build the frameworks, the final structures have greater tunability . The ancillary bridging imidazole or pyridine linkers holding different lengths and flexibilities have great effects on the final architectures and topology as well as coordination modes and molecular conformations of multicarboxylate acids . Therefore, preparing novel functional MOFs using such kinds of flexible multicarboxylate and ancillary bridging imidazole or pyridine linkers should be attempted. In this article, we have chosen the flexible multicarboxylic acid, namely, 5,5′-(butane-1,4-diyl)-bis(oxy)-diisophthalic acid (H4L), and two ancillary bridging imidazole or pyridine linkers, namely, 4,4-bipyridine (4,4′-bpy)  and 1,4-bis (1H-imidazol-1-yl)-butane (bib) . Herein, three 3D 3-fold interpenetrated frameworks were obtained through a mix ligand strategy under similar solvothermal reactions, [Zn(L)0.5(4,4′-bpy)]·2(H2O) (1), [M (L)0.5(bib)]·4(H2O) (M = Zn (2), Co (3)) (). Moreover, the syntheses, crystal structures, topologies, thermal stabilities and photoluminescent properties are reported in this paper.

Experimental section
Materials and general methods
The ligands H4L and bib were prepared according to the literature . Other chemicals were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification, such as K2CO3 (A.R., ≥99% ), Zn(NO3)2
·6H2O (A.R., ≥99%) Co(NO3)2
·6H2O (A. R., ≥99%) NaOH (A.R., ≥99%), 4,4′-bpy (A.R., ≥99%), CH3OH (A.R., ≥99%), 5-hydroxy-isophthalic acid diethyl ester (A.R., ≥98%), 1,4-dichlorobutane (A.R., ≥98%), and so on. Fourier Transform Infrared Spectra (FT-IR) were measured on Nexus-670FT spectrum instrument at the range of 4000–400cm−1 using KBr pellets. Compounds 1–3 were examined by and TEM (FEI Tecnai G2 F20 200kV) (), and compounds 1 and 2 were examined by SEM (Hitachi S4800 SEM and Bruker QUANTAX 200 EDX) at accelerating voltage up to 10 KV (). The Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 CHNS elemental analyzer. Thermogravimetric analyses were performed on a STA409pc thermogravimetric analyzer from 30 to 700°C at a heating rate 10°Cmin−1 under air atmosphere. Powder X-ray diffractometer (PXRD) was performed on a X’Pert PRO (PW3071/xx Bracket) diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ=1.5406Å). UV–vis spectra were measured on a TU-1901 UV–vis spectrophotometer in the solid state at room temperature. Solid-state photoluminescent spectra were measured on an Edinburgh FLS920 fluorescence spectrometer at room temperature 
.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sect0035">Synthesis</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sect0040">Synthesis of 5,5′-(butane-1,4-diyl)-bis(oxy)-diisophthalic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">5-hydroxy-isophthalic acid diethyl ester (2.38<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and anhydrous K<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 22<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) were put in a 50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL round bottom flask under nitrogen atmosphere and treated with 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL of dry DMF. The reaction mixture was stirred for 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h at 70<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C followed by addition of 1,4-dichlorobutane (0.64<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), and the resulting mixture was stirred for 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h in an oil-bath at 80<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. At the end of the period, the solution was allowed to cool to room temperature and then poured into ice-water (100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) with vigorous stirring that afforded a white precipitated (tetraethyl 5,5′-(butane-1,4-diyl)-bis(oxy)-diisophthalate) which was collected by filtration, washed with water three times, and dried in air. Then the tetraethyl 5,5′-(butane-1,4-diyl)-bis(oxy) diisophthalate (2.65<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was hydrolyzed by refluxing it with 95% ethanol solution for 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h followed by addition of NaOH (0.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and the reaction mixture was refluxed for 15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h in an oil-bath. Finally, the resulting solution was poured into ice-water (100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) with vigorous stirring and was acidified carefully with 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M HCl to obtain a white precipitate. After keeping it overnight in the freezer, the white solid was collected by filtration and dried at air. Yield: 2.02<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g (96%). FT-IR (KBr, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3096.35(s), 2961(s), 1697(s), 1597(m), 1462(m), 1402(m), 1273(m), 1126(w), 1051(m), 909(w), 759(w), 668(w), 530(w), 479(w).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis
Synthesis of 5,5′-(butane-1,4-diyl)-bis(oxy)-diisophthalic acid (H4L)
5-hydroxy-isophthalic acid diethyl ester (2.38g, 10mmol) and anhydrous K2CO3 (3g, 22mmol) were put in a 50mL round bottom flask under nitrogen atmosphere and treated with 20mL of dry DMF. The reaction mixture was stirred for 1h at 70°C followed by addition of 1,4-dichlorobutane (0.64g, 5mmol), and the resulting mixture was stirred for 20h in an oil-bath at 80°C. At the end of the period, the solution was allowed to cool to room temperature and then poured into ice-water (100mL) with vigorous stirring that afforded a white precipitated (tetraethyl 5,5′-(butane-1,4-diyl)-bis(oxy)-diisophthalate) which was collected by filtration, washed with water three times, and dried in air. Then the tetraethyl 5,5′-(butane-1,4-diyl)-bis(oxy) diisophthalate (2.65g, 5mmol) was hydrolyzed by refluxing it with 95% ethanol solution for 1h followed by addition of NaOH (0.8g, 20mmol) and the reaction mixture was refluxed for 15h in an oil-bath. Finally, the resulting solution was poured into ice-water (100mL) with vigorous stirring and was acidified carefully with 4M HCl to obtain a white precipitate. After keeping it overnight in the freezer, the white solid was collected by filtration and dried at air. Yield: 2.02g (96%). FT-IR (KBr, cm−1): 3096.35(s), 2961(s), 1697(s), 1597(m), 1462(m), 1402(m), 1273(m), 1126(w), 1051(m), 909(w), 759(w), 668(w), 530(w), 479(w).

Synthesis of [Zn(L)0.5(4,4′-bpy)]·2(H2O) (1)
A solution of Zn(NO3)2
·(H2O)6 (0.0145g, 0.05mmol) in CH3OH (0.5mL) and a solution of 4,4′-bpy (0.0096g, 0.05mmol) in CH3OH (0.5mL)were added with stirring to a solution of H4L (0.0104g, 0.025mmol) in DMF (1mL), then 2mLH2O was added to this mixture solution. After the mixture solution was stirred for 20min, 2 drops of 1mol/L HNO3 solution was added to this reaction solution, and then the reaction mixture solution were stirred for another 20min. The colorless solution had been obtained and then sealed in a 5mL sealing glass vessel. The vessel was heated to 80°C and held at that temperature for 48h, then slowly cooling to room temperature, block crystals of 1 for single crystal X-ray diffraction were obtained by filtration and dried at air. yield:80%. Anal. Caled.(%): C 52.09, H 4.08, N 6.02. Found (%): C 52.62, H 4.17, N 5.94. EDX El. AN. (wt%): Zn 11.41, O 26.07, C 54.95, N 7.57. (at%): Zn 2.52, O 23.55, C 66.12, N 7.81. <ce:section-title id="sect0055">X-ray crystallography</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0035" view="all">Single-crystal X-ray data for compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were collected on an Bruker Smart Apex Ⅱ CCD diffractometer using graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ=1.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) at room temperature. Empirical absorption correction was applied. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by the full-matrix least-squares methods on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> using the SHELXTL-97 software . All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. All of the hydrogen atoms were placed in the calculated positions. Pertinent crystallographic data collection and parameters are collated in <ce:float-anchor refid="t0005"></ce:float-anchor>
. Selected bond lengths and angles are collated in . Topological analyses of the compounds were performed by using the TOPOS software . CCDC-1444200, CCDC-1471013 and CCDC-1444201 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for compound <ce:bold>1, 2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, respectively. These data can be obtained free of charge from the Cambridge crystallographic data centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography
Single-crystal X-ray data for compound 1–3 were collected on an Bruker Smart Apex Ⅱ CCD diffractometer using graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ=1.71073Å) at room temperature. Empirical absorption correction was applied. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by the full-matrix least-squares methods on F
2 using the SHELXTL-97 software . All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. All of the hydrogen atoms were placed in the calculated positions. Pertinent crystallographic data collection and parameters are collated in 
. Selected bond lengths and angles are collated in . Topological analyses of the compounds were performed by using the TOPOS software . CCDC-1444200, CCDC-1471013 and CCDC-1444201 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for compound 1, 2 and 3, respectively. These data can be obtained free of charge from the Cambridge crystallographic data centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sect0060">Result and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sect0065">Synthesis and general characterization</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">All crystallization of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were synthesized under similar reaction conditions by solvothermal methods, by changing metal ions and solvent, the single crystals suitable for the single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis were finally obtained. For compounds <ce:bold>1–3</ce:bold>, the measured PXRD patterns closely match the simulated patterns generated from the results of Single-Crystal Diffraction data, indicating pure phases of 1–3 products (). The IR spectra of H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L and compound <ce:bold>1–3</ce:bold> also show characteristic the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of the carboxylate groups are observed in the ranges of 1597–1621 and 1346–1402<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, respectively  ().</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Result and discussion
Synthesis and general characterization
All crystallization of compounds 1–3 were synthesized under similar reaction conditions by solvothermal methods, by changing metal ions and solvent, the single crystals suitable for the single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis were finally obtained. For compounds 1–3, the measured PXRD patterns closely match the simulated patterns generated from the results of Single-Crystal Diffraction data, indicating pure phases of 1–3 products (). The IR spectra of H4L and compound 1–3 also show characteristic the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of the carboxylate groups are observed in the ranges of 1597–1621 and 1346–1402cm−1, respectively  ().

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sect0070">Structure descriptions</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sect0075">Description of crystal structure of compound 1</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0045" view="all">Single-crystal X-ray structure determination of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> reveals a 3-fold interpenetrated three-dimensional (3D) framework that crystallizes in the monoclinic space group <ce:italic>P21/c</ce:italic>. The relevant asymmetric unit consists of one crystallographically independent Zn(Ⅱ) ion in a distorted tetrahedral geometry, a half of coordinated L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligand, one coordinated 4,4′-bpy and two lattice water molecules. The coordination geometry around the Zn(Ⅱ) metal ion is found to be distorted tetrahedral.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Structure descriptions
Description of crystal structure of compound 1
Single-crystal X-ray structure determination of compound 1 reveals a 3-fold interpenetrated three-dimensional (3D) framework that crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c. The relevant asymmetric unit consists of one crystallographically independent Zn(Ⅱ) ion in a distorted tetrahedral geometry, a half of coordinated L4− ligand, one coordinated 4,4′-bpy and two lattice water molecules. The coordination geometry around the Zn(Ⅱ) metal ion is found to be distorted tetrahedral.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0050" view="all">The tetrahedral [ZnN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] geometry around the Zn(Ⅱ) metal ion is comprised of two oxygen atoms from two different L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligand units, and two nitrogen atoms from two different 4,4′-bpy ligands (<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>
(a)). The bond distances of Zn-O and Zn-N are in the range 1.952–2.079<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and the bond angles around the Zn (Ⅱ) centre are in the range 95.38–132.51°. In the compound 1, on the one hand the 4,4′-bpy ligand connects two tetrahedral [ZnN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] centres in the 1D metal-pyridyl chains through the N atoms of the pyridyl rings with a separation of 10.9588<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å resulting in the formation of a V-shaped chain as shown in (b). In the 1D metal-pyridyl chain, the dihedral angle between two pyridyl rings is 13.022°. Therefore, two pyridyl rings of 4,4′-bpy are not coplanar. On the other hand each L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligand connects to four [ZnN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] tetrahedrons at four orientational positions by a μ<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>-η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">0</ce:sup> monodentate modes forming a 2D network, characterized by the C<ce:inf loc="post">phenyl</ce:inf>-O…O-C<ce:inf loc="post">phenyl</ce:inf> torsion angle of 180° in the central part of the L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligand, and the torsion angle of C<ce:inf loc="post">phenyl</ce:inf>-O…CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2,</ce:inf> O-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>…CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2,</ce:inf> CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>…CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>…CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-O, and CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>… O-C<ce:inf loc="post">phenyl</ce:inf> is 178°, 179°, 180°, 179°, and 178° in the L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligand, and the dihedral angle between two phenyl rings of L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> is 0°, hence all oxygen and carbon atoms of the L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup>are mainly coplanar((c)). Finally, the 2D network structures formed by L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligand and [ZnN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] tetrahedra were interconnected by the 1D metal-pyridyl chains to form a 3D framework with channels (15.0977<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å×22.2255<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) (<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>
(a)). The 3D grid allows each frameworks to be penetrated by two other independent frameworks to form the interesting 3-fold interpenetrating 3D frameworks, with isolated water molecules occupying the neutral channels ((b)).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
The tetrahedral [ZnN2O2] geometry around the Zn(Ⅱ) metal ion is comprised of two oxygen atoms from two different L4− ligand units, and two nitrogen atoms from two different 4,4′-bpy ligands (
(a)). The bond distances of Zn-O and Zn-N are in the range 1.952–2.079Å and the bond angles around the Zn (Ⅱ) centre are in the range 95.38–132.51°. In the compound 1, on the one hand the 4,4′-bpy ligand connects two tetrahedral [ZnN2O2] centres in the 1D metal-pyridyl chains through the N atoms of the pyridyl rings with a separation of 10.9588Å resulting in the formation of a V-shaped chain as shown in (b). In the 1D metal-pyridyl chain, the dihedral angle between two pyridyl rings is 13.022°. Therefore, two pyridyl rings of 4,4′-bpy are not coplanar. On the other hand each L4− ligand connects to four [ZnN2O2] tetrahedrons at four orientational positions by a μ1-η1: η0 monodentate modes forming a 2D network, characterized by the Cphenyl-O…O-Cphenyl torsion angle of 180° in the central part of the L4− ligand, and the torsion angle of Cphenyl-O…CH2-CH2, O-CH2…CH2-CH2, CH2-CH2…CH2-CH2, CH2-CH2…CH2-O, and CH2-CH2… O-Cphenyl is 178°, 179°, 180°, 179°, and 178° in the L4− ligand, and the dihedral angle between two phenyl rings of L4− is 0°, hence all oxygen and carbon atoms of the L4−are mainly coplanar((c)). Finally, the 2D network structures formed by L4− ligand and [ZnN2O2] tetrahedra were interconnected by the 1D metal-pyridyl chains to form a 3D framework with channels (15.0977Å×22.2255Å) (
(a)). The 3D grid allows each frameworks to be penetrated by two other independent frameworks to form the interesting 3-fold interpenetrating 3D frameworks, with isolated water molecules occupying the neutral channels ((b)).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0055" view="all">A better insight into the nature of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be provided by a topology analysis. The extension of the structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> into a (4,4)-connected <ce:bold>bbf</ce:bold> topology net  is accomplished by binding two L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligands and two bib ligands to the four-connected Zn (Ⅱ) nodes. The L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligands can be simplified as a four-connected node, the bib ligands are taken as linkers, and the 3D structure can be simplified as a 4-connected net with the Schläfli symbol of (6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>·8<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)(6<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>) ((c)). The topological analysis of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> reveals that the individual 3D framework has spacious space, it allows another two identical 3D frameworks to interpenetrate it in a normal mode giving a 3-fold interpenetrated 3D to 3D frameworks ((d)).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: A better insight into the nature of compound 1 can be provided by a topology analysis. The extension of the structure of 1 into a (4,4)-connected bbf topology net  is accomplished by binding two L4− ligands and two bib ligands to the four-connected Zn (Ⅱ) nodes. The L4− ligands can be simplified as a four-connected node, the bib ligands are taken as linkers, and the 3D structure can be simplified as a 4-connected net with the Schläfli symbol of (64·82)(66) ((c)). The topological analysis of 1 reveals that the individual 3D framework has spacious space, it allows another two identical 3D frameworks to interpenetrate it in a normal mode giving a 3-fold interpenetrated 3D to 3D frameworks ((d)).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="sect0080">Description of crystal structure of compound 2 and 3</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">When the auxiliary ligand was changed from rigid 4,4′-bpy to flexible bib used in the preparation for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. The results of Single-crystal X-ray structure determination show that the structure of compound 2 are similar to that of compound 3, so we describe the structure of the compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> as an example, compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> with a 3D framework crystallizes in the monoclinic space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic>. The asymmetric unit contains one independent Co(Ⅱ) ion, a half of coordinated L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligand, one coordinated bib and four lattice water molecules. As shown in <ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>
(a), the Co (Ⅱ) metal ion is four-coordinated by two oxygen atoms from two different L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligand units, and two nitrogen atoms from two bib ligands respectively. The bond distances of Co-O and Co-N are in the range 1.963–2.024<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and the bond angles around the Co (Ⅱ) centre are in the range 97.56–124.01°. In the compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, the N-donor imidazolyl ligand bib occurs in one kind of coordination mode.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Description of crystal structure of compound 2 and 3
When the auxiliary ligand was changed from rigid 4,4′-bpy to flexible bib used in the preparation for 2 and 3. The results of Single-crystal X-ray structure determination show that the structure of compound 2 are similar to that of compound 3, so we describe the structure of the compound 3 as an example, compound 3 with a 3D framework crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c. The asymmetric unit contains one independent Co(Ⅱ) ion, a half of coordinated L4− ligand, one coordinated bib and four lattice water molecules. As shown in 
(a), the Co (Ⅱ) metal ion is four-coordinated by two oxygen atoms from two different L4− ligand units, and two nitrogen atoms from two bib ligands respectively. The bond distances of Co-O and Co-N are in the range 1.963–2.024Å and the bond angles around the Co (Ⅱ) centre are in the range 97.56–124.01°. In the compound 3, the N-donor imidazolyl ligand bib occurs in one kind of coordination mode.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0065" view="all">The bib ligand connects two tetrahedral [CoN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] centres in the 1D metal-imidazolyl chains through the N atoms of the imidazolyl rings, creating a separation of 13.61<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å to form a V-shaped chain as shown in (b). In the 1D structure, the flexible bib exhibits <ce:italic>anti–gauche–anti</ce:italic> conformation and the dihedral angle between two imidazolyl rings is 62.015°. In compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, each L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligand connects to four Co atoms at four angles in a μ<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>-η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">0</ce:sup> monodentate modes and connects the [CoN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] tetrahedra in a 2D network conformation, characterized by the C<ce:inf loc="post">phenyl</ce:inf>-O…O-C<ce:inf loc="post">phenyl</ce:inf> torsion angle of 180° in the central part of the L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligand and the dihedral angle between two phenyl rings is 0°, but the torsion angle of C<ce:inf loc="post">phenyl</ce:inf>-O…CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2,</ce:inf> O-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>…CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2,</ce:inf> CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>…CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>…CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-O, and CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>…O-C<ce:inf loc="post">phenyl</ce:inf> is 157.94°, 83.55°, 180°, 83.55°, and 157.94°, respectively. The two phenyl rings of L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> is coplanar, but a great changes have taken place in the -(CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>- of L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligand ((c)). In this compound, the 2D network structure formed by L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligand and [CoN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] tetrahedra was linked by the 1D metal-imidazolyl chains to form a 3D framework with channels (18.1567<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å×24.0957<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) (<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>
(a)). Longer length of co-ligand (bib) in compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> than that of co-ligand (bpy) in compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> resulted in that compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> exhibit larger channels of individual 3D frameworks in size (18.1567<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å×24.0957<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) than those (15.0977<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å×22.2255<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. Correspondingly, compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> with larger channels size accommodate more H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecules than compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. The 3D grid allows each frameworks to be penetrated by two other independent frameworks to form the interesting 3D 3-fold interpenetrating frameworks with isolated water molecules occupying the neutral channels ((b), S5).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
The bib ligand connects two tetrahedral [CoN2O2] centres in the 1D metal-imidazolyl chains through the N atoms of the imidazolyl rings, creating a separation of 13.61Å to form a V-shaped chain as shown in (b). In the 1D structure, the flexible bib exhibits anti–gauche–anti conformation and the dihedral angle between two imidazolyl rings is 62.015°. In compound 3, each L4− ligand connects to four Co atoms at four angles in a μ1-η1: η0 monodentate modes and connects the [CoN2O2] tetrahedra in a 2D network conformation, characterized by the Cphenyl-O…O-Cphenyl torsion angle of 180° in the central part of the L4− ligand and the dihedral angle between two phenyl rings is 0°, but the torsion angle of Cphenyl-O…CH2-CH2, O-CH2…CH2-CH2, CH2-CH2…CH2-CH2, CH2-CH2…CH2-O, and CH2-CH2…O-Cphenyl is 157.94°, 83.55°, 180°, 83.55°, and 157.94°, respectively. The two phenyl rings of L4− is coplanar, but a great changes have taken place in the -(CH2)4- of L4− ligand ((c)). In this compound, the 2D network structure formed by L4− ligand and [CoN2O2] tetrahedra was linked by the 1D metal-imidazolyl chains to form a 3D framework with channels (18.1567Å×24.0957Å) (
(a)). Longer length of co-ligand (bib) in compound 2 and 3 than that of co-ligand (bpy) in compound 1 resulted in that compound 2 and 3 exhibit larger channels of individual 3D frameworks in size (18.1567Å×24.0957Å) than those (15.0977Å×22.2255Å) of compound 1. Correspondingly, compound 2 and 3 with larger channels size accommodate more H2O molecules than compound 1. The 3D grid allows each frameworks to be penetrated by two other independent frameworks to form the interesting 3D 3-fold interpenetrating frameworks with isolated water molecules occupying the neutral channels ((b), S5).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0070" view="all">From the view of topology, by treating the Co (Ⅱ) atoms and the L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligands as a four-connected node, the bib ligands are taken as linkers, the 3D single framework can be simplified as a (4,4)-connected <ce:bold>bbf</ce:bold> topology net, like compound <ce:bold>1,</ce:bold> with the Schläfli symbol of (6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>·8<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)(6<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>) ((c)). The topological analysis of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> reveals that the 3D individual framework have spacious space, it allows another two identical 3D single frameworks to interpenetrate it in a normal mode giving a 3-fold interpenetrated 3D to 3D framework ((d)).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: From the view of topology, by treating the Co (Ⅱ) atoms and the L4− ligands as a four-connected node, the bib ligands are taken as linkers, the 3D single framework can be simplified as a (4,4)-connected bbf topology net, like compound 1, with the Schläfli symbol of (64·82)(66) ((c)). The topological analysis of 3 reveals that the 3D individual framework have spacious space, it allows another two identical 3D single frameworks to interpenetrate it in a normal mode giving a 3-fold interpenetrated 3D to 3D framework ((d)).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="sect0085">PXRD studies and thermogravimetric analyses</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0075" view="all">The simulated of single X-ray diffraction data and experimental PXRD patterns of compounds 1–3 obtained at room temperature are shown in (<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0030"></ce:float-anchor>
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0035"></ce:float-anchor>
). Rietveld full-profile fitting results based on the structural parameters of compounds 1–3 indicate the positions of the major diffraction peaks are in agreement with those calculated single crystal data (). The difference intensities between simulated and experimental patterns may be due to the variation in preferred orientation of crystalline powder samples during collection of the experimental XRD data.</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0080" view="all">Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) and Differential thermal gravity (DTG) for the H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L and the crystalline samples of compounds <ce:bold>1–3</ce:bold> were recorded under air atmosphere in the temperature range of 30–700<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (<ce:float-anchor refid="f0040"></ce:float-anchor>
, ). The TGA curves of all three compounds have released the lattice water before 350<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, reflecting the fact that the lattice water in the framework is unstable and easy to separate from framework at low temperatures. The first weight losses corresponding to the release of water molecules are observed before 365<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (observed 9.12%, calculated 7.83%), 323<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (observed 11.36%, calculated 13.69%), 325<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> (observed 16.34%, calculated 13.84%). The anhydrous compositions begin to decompose at 365<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and ending above 490<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, at 323<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and ending above 497<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, and at 325<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and ending above 417<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, due to the decomposition of the organic part of the framework. The remaining weight may correspond to the formation of ZnO for compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (observed 18.14%, calculated 17.72%) and compound 2 (observed 20.12%, calculated 15.39%), CoO for compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> (observed 15.63%, calculated 14.42%).</ce:para>

Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) and Differential thermal gravity (DTG) for the H4L and the crystalline samples of compounds 1–3 were recorded under air atmosphere in the temperature range of 30–700°C (

The TGA curves of all three compounds have released the lattice water before 350°C, reflecting the fact that the lattice water in the framework is unstable and easy to separate from framework at low temperatures. The first weight losses corresponding to the release of water molecules are observed before 365°C for compound 1 (observed 9.12%, calculated 7.83%), 323°C for compound 2 (observed 11.36%, calculated 13.69%), 325°C for compound 3 (observed 16.34%, calculated 13.84%). The anhydrous compositions begin to decompose at 365°C and ending above 490°C for 1, at 323°C and ending above 497°C for 2, and at 325°C and ending above 417°C for 3, due to the decomposition of the organic part of the framework. The remaining weight may correspond to the formation of ZnO for compound 1 (observed 18.14%, calculated 17.72%) and compound 2 (observed 20.12%, calculated 15.39%), CoO for compound 3 (observed 15.63%, calculated 14.42%).

<ce:section-title id="sect0090">UV–vis absorption spectra of compound 1-3</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0085" view="all">The UV–vis spectra of compound <ce:bold>1–3</ce:bold> together with the free H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L ligand in the solid state at room temperature were measured. The Kubelka-Munk functions  converted from the diffuse reflectance data were plotted in <ce:float-anchor refid="f0045"></ce:float-anchor>
. The H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L exhibits strong absorption with a maximum at 316<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm in the range of 280−352<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, which probably corresponds to the π-π* and <ce:italic>n</ce:italic>-π* transitions centered on the benzene ring. The absorption of 4,4′-bpy is strong in a similar range with one peak at 290<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm . Compared to the free H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L ligand, compound <ce:bold>1–3</ce:bold> exhibit absorption with maxima at 307<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, 308<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, 305<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, respectively, and the absorption peaks of compounds <ce:bold>1, 2,</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> have slightly blue-shifted in the same range. In compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the absorption peak is more stronger than other compound at 280<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, which may be attributed to the effect of 4,4′-bpy. In compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, the characteristic absorption bands of UV–vis spectra around 580<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm are correlated with the d-d transitions of tetrahedral coordinated Co<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>
.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
UV–vis absorption spectra of compound 1-3
The UV–vis spectra of compound 1–3 together with the free H4L ligand in the solid state at room temperature were measured. The Kubelka-Munk functions  converted from the diffuse reflectance data were plotted in 
. The H4L exhibits strong absorption with a maximum at 316nm in the range of 280−352nm, which probably corresponds to the π-π* and n-π* transitions centered on the benzene ring. The absorption of 4,4′-bpy is strong in a similar range with one peak at 290nm . Compared to the free H4L ligand, compound 1–3 exhibit absorption with maxima at 307nm, 308nm, 305nm, respectively, and the absorption peaks of compounds 1, 2, and 3 have slightly blue-shifted in the same range. In compound 1, the absorption peak is more stronger than other compound at 280nm, which may be attributed to the effect of 4,4′-bpy. In compound 3, the characteristic absorption bands of UV–vis spectra around 580nm are correlated with the d-d transitions of tetrahedral coordinated Co2+
.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="sect0095">Photoluminescence properties</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0090" view="all">The metal-organic frameworks are promising candidates for applicable photoluminescent materials such as chemical sensors, light emitting diodes, electro-chemical sensors and so on. Although a lot of transition metal ions and rare-earth ions have been used to construct MOFs, the Zn-based MOFs are the most interested transition metal based luminescent MOFs. The d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> metal ions not only have various coordination numbers and geometries, but also display luminescent properties with functional ligands . The photoluminescence properties of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> together with the free H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L ligand, were investigated in the solid state at room temperature (<ce:float-anchor refid="t0010"></ce:float-anchor>
) and depicted in <ce:float-anchor refid="f0050"></ce:float-anchor>
, S4. The photoluminescent spectra of the free ligands show the main peak at 412<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf>=339 ) for H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L, 466<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf>=390<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm) for 4,4′-bpy , 436<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf>=380<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm) for bib , respectively, which may be caused by the π*-π and π*-<ce:italic>n</ce:italic> transition. The emission spectra for bands were observed at 452<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf>=337<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm) for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 401 and 418<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf>=348<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm) for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. As the literature reported, the d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> configured Zn(Ⅱ) cations are electrochemically inert, therefore, when coordinated by ligands, they cannot take an electron from the ligand with their 3d-orbitals, nor donate an electron to the ligand . In comparison to the free ligands, the emission maxima of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is red-shifted by 40<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm as compared to free H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L ligand, and close to the free 4,4′-bpy ligand, inferring their emission bands may be assigned to the intra-ligand charge transfer (ILCT), neither metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) nor ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) happened. The emission peaks of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are close to free H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L ligand, so the emission bands of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> can probably be attributed to the intra-ligand charge transfer (ILCT). Experimental results show that compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is non-emissive under similar conditions, indicating the emissions of organic ligands may be quenched completely in the compound, which may be due to the emission quencher of Co (Ⅱ) in the structure. In term of the structures and emission spectra of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, it is inferred that different ligands co-ligands may be an important factor on influencing different luminescent properties of compounds .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescence properties
The metal-organic frameworks are promising candidates for applicable photoluminescent materials such as chemical sensors, light emitting diodes, electro-chemical sensors and so on. Although a lot of transition metal ions and rare-earth ions have been used to construct MOFs, the Zn-based MOFs are the most interested transition metal based luminescent MOFs. The d10 metal ions not only have various coordination numbers and geometries, but also display luminescent properties with functional ligands . The photoluminescence properties of compound 1 and 2 together with the free H4L ligand, were investigated in the solid state at room temperature (
) and depicted in 
, S4. The photoluminescent spectra of the free ligands show the main peak at 412nm (λex=339 ) for H4L, 466nm (λex=390nm) for 4,4′-bpy , 436nm (λex=380nm) for bib , respectively, which may be caused by the π*-π and π*-n transition. The emission spectra for bands were observed at 452nm (λex=337nm) for 1, 401 and 418nm (λex=348nm) for 2. As the literature reported, the d10 configured Zn(Ⅱ) cations are electrochemically inert, therefore, when coordinated by ligands, they cannot take an electron from the ligand with their 3d-orbitals, nor donate an electron to the ligand . In comparison to the free ligands, the emission maxima of 1 is red-shifted by 40nm as compared to free H4L ligand, and close to the free 4,4′-bpy ligand, inferring their emission bands may be assigned to the intra-ligand charge transfer (ILCT), neither metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) nor ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) happened. The emission peaks of 2 are close to free H4L ligand, so the emission bands of 2 can probably be attributed to the intra-ligand charge transfer (ILCT). Experimental results show that compound 3 is non-emissive under similar conditions, indicating the emissions of organic ligands may be quenched completely in the compound, which may be due to the emission quencher of Co (Ⅱ) in the structure. In term of the structures and emission spectra of compound 1 and 2, it is inferred that different ligands co-ligands may be an important factor on influencing different luminescent properties of compounds .

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sect0100">Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0095" view="all">In summary, we successfully designed and synthesized three coordination polymers based on flexible multicarboxylic acid 5,5′-(butane-1,4-diyl)-bis(oxy)-diisophthalic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L), and one rigid ancillary bridging pyridine linkers 4,4′ -bipyridine (4,4′-bpy) for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, one flexible ancillary imidazole linkers 1,4-bis (1H-imidazol-1-yl)-butane (bib) for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. These compounds display interesting and versatile coordination features from 3D to 3D parallel entangled frameworks. Topological analysis reveals that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are 3D (4,4)-connected <ce:bold>bbf</ce:bold> topology net with the (6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>·8<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)(6<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>) topology. The adjustable channels size of individual 3D framework is realized by using different lengths of co-ligands from byp to bib with keeping similar architectures of compounds <ce:bold>1–3</ce:bold>. In compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, the assignment of characteristic absorption bands of UV–vis spectra at 580<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm correlated with the d-d transitions of Co<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions in field of tetrahedral coordination is confirmed by the result of the single-crystal X-ray structure analysis. The solid-state photoluminescent properties of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were investigated, and the emission bands were assigned to the intra-ligand charge transfer (ILCT), and the different emission wavelength due to the effect of co-ligands. The solid-state thermal stabilities were investigated. The frameworks of <ce:bold>1, 2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are stable under 350<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions
In summary, we successfully designed and synthesized three coordination polymers based on flexible multicarboxylic acid 5,5′-(butane-1,4-diyl)-bis(oxy)-diisophthalic acid (H4L), and one rigid ancillary bridging pyridine linkers 4,4′ -bipyridine (4,4′-bpy) for 1, one flexible ancillary imidazole linkers 1,4-bis (1H-imidazol-1-yl)-butane (bib) for 2 and 3. These compounds display interesting and versatile coordination features from 3D to 3D parallel entangled frameworks. Topological analysis reveals that 1–3 are 3D (4,4)-connected bbf topology net with the (64·82)(66) topology. The adjustable channels size of individual 3D framework is realized by using different lengths of co-ligands from byp to bib with keeping similar architectures of compounds 1–3. In compound 3, the assignment of characteristic absorption bands of UV–vis spectra at 580nm correlated with the d-d transitions of Co2+ ions in field of tetrahedral coordination is confirmed by the result of the single-crystal X-ray structure analysis. The solid-state photoluminescent properties of 1 and 2 were investigated, and the emission bands were assigned to the intra-ligand charge transfer (ILCT), and the different emission wavelength due to the effect of co-ligands. The solid-state thermal stabilities were investigated. The frameworks of 1, 2 and 3 are stable under 350°C.
